tit.cmt: ・「大高 元恭」が初出しているので漢字表記もこちらへ移動しました。

sen.j: 大高 元恭（おおだか もとやす、宝暦8年10月16日 (旧暦)（1758年11月16日） - 文政末年）は蘭学の草創期に活躍した日本の医師、蘭学者。
sen.e: Motoyasu ODAKA (大高 元恭) (November 16, 1758 - 1830) was a Japanese doctor and scholar of Western sciences in the period in which the Western sciences were introduced.
sen.cmt: 「元恭」→後の文で元喬とも書く、と出てくるので、区別するため漢字表記を挿入しました。「文政末年」→1830年。（http://kotobank.jp/word/%E6%96%87%E6%94%BF）
sen.e: Motoyasu ODAKA (November 16, 1758 - 1830) was a Japanese doctor and Rangakusha or a Dutch scholar (a person who studied Western sciences by means of the Dutch language) in the period that the Western sciences were introduced.
sen.cmt: ・「大高 元恭」が初出しているのはタイトル部なので、漢字表記は上へ移動しました。・用語集の用語検索を参考に「蘭学者」の表記を変更しました。初出なので詳しい説明を付けています。
sen.e: Motoyasu ODAKA (November 16, 1758 - 1830) was a Japanese doctor and Rangakusha or a Dutch scholar (a person who studied Western sciences by means of the Dutch language) in the period that the Western sciences were introduced.

sen.j: 本草学者。
sen.e: Scholar of herbalism.
Scholar of herbalism.
Scholar of herbalism.

sen.j: 箸尾元恭とも名乗ったが、高階氏であったため大高と称した。
sen.e: He also called himself Motoyasu HASHIO, but came to call his surname as Odaka, because he was from the Takashina clan.
He also called himself Motoyasu HASHIO, but came to call his surname as Odaka, because he was from the Takashina clan.
He also called himself Motoyasu HASHIO, but came to call his surname as Odaka, because he was from the Takashina clan.

sen.j: 元喬と記載されることもある。
sen.e: His name is sometimes written as 元喬.
His name is sometimes written as 元喬 instead of 元恭.
sen.cmt: ・”「元恭」ではなく”という意味を追加した方が、読み手に漢字の違いが分かりやすいかと思い修正しました。
sen.e: His name is sometimes written as 元喬 instead of 元恭.

sen.j: 初名は和三郎、次に宗温と名乗り、その後清福庵宗粛と号する。
sen.e: He was originally called Wasaburo, then Soon, later Seifukuan Soshuku.
sen.cmt: 「宗温」→志野宗温など、「そうおん」と読むのが一般的のようです。「宗粛」→読み方確認できませんでしたが、○○庵××の場合、通常は音読みと思われますので、「そうしゅく」としました。
sen.e: He was originally called Wasaburo, then Soon, later Seifukuan Soshuku.
He was originally called Wasaburo, then Soon, later Seifukuan Soshuku.

sen.j: 字は知道。
sen.e: His azana (name taken by scholars and artists after a Chinese custom) was Chido.
His azana (name taken by scholars and artists after a Chinese custom) was Chido.
His azana (name taken by scholars and artists after a Chinese custom) was Chido.

sen.j: 略歴
sen.e: Brief Personal History
Brief Personal History
Brief Personal History

sen.j: 大坂で延寿院流の医業を営んだ父大高養哲（箸尾師明）と母・周（柴田氏）のもとに生まれた。
sen.e: He was born as a son of his father Yotetsu ODAKA (Moroaki HASHIO) and mother 周 (from the Shibata clan).
sen.cmt: 「周」→読み方不明。人名で「あまね」と読むようですが、一般的には男性名のようです。
sen.e: He was born as a son of his father Yotetsu ODAKA (Moroaki HASHIO) and mother Shu or Amane (from the Shibata clan).
sen.cmt: ・校正でも「周」の読み方が分かりませんでしたが、orを用いて一般的な読み方を複数併記しました。必要なければ削除願います。
sen.e: He was born as a son of his father Yotetsu ODAKA (Moroaki HASHIO) and mother Shu or Amane (from the Shibata clan).

sen.j: 本草物産家として知られ、寛政から文化 (元号)・文政頃には大阪の医師番付で高く評価されていた。
sen.e: He was known as a herbal naturalist, and highly valued in a list of doctors in Osaka from Kansei to Bunka and Bunsei era.
He was known as a herbal naturalist, and highly valued in a list of doctors in Osaka from Kansei to Bunka and Bunsei era.
He was known as a herbal naturalist, and highly valued in a list of doctors in Osaka from Kansei to Bunka and Bunsei era.

sen.j: 寛政版の『浪華郷友録』その他にも醫家、物産家として名前が挙げられている。
sen.e: His name appears as a doctor and naturalist in "Naniwa Kyoyuroku" (Directory of Osaka), published in Kansei era, and also in other publications.
His name appears as a doctor and naturalist in "Naniwa Kyoyuroku" (Directory of Osaka), published in Kansei era, and also in other publications.
His name appears as a doctor and naturalist in "Naniwa Kyoyuroku" (Directory of Osaka), published in Kansei era, and also in other publications.

sen.j: 本草学者としての学識に加えて、蘭学にも造詣が深く、橋本宗吉の代表作『西洋医事集成宝凾』の校閲を行った。
sen.e: He was familiar with Western sciences as well as herbalism, and reviewed "Seiyo Iji Shusei Hokan" (Treasure Chest of Collected Western Medical Facts), a representative work of Sokichi HASHIMOTO.
He was familiar with Western sciences as well as herbalism, and reviewed "Seiyo Iji Shusei Hokan" (Treasure Chest of Collected Western Medical Facts), a representative work of Sokichi HASHIMOTO.
He was familiar with Western sciences as well as herbalism, and reviewed "Seiyo Iji Shusei Hokan" (Treasure Chest of Collected Western Medical Facts), a representative work of Sokichi HASHIMOTO.

sen.j: 学医として当時の浪花で五本の指に入る存在として知られた。
sen.e: He was known as one of the five best doctors in Osaka at that time.
He was known as one of the five best doctors in Osaka at that time.
He was known as one of the five best doctors in Osaka at that time.

sen.j: 嘉永5年（1852年）成立、安政元年（1854年）刊の『西洋学家訳述目録』にその名が見え、西洋の医学書の和訳、『醫方集要』全十巻を著したことでも知られる。
sen.e: His name appears in "Seiyo Gakka Yakujutsu Mokuroku" (Bibliography of Translations of Western Writings) completed in 1852 and published in 1854, as the author of ten-volume "Iho Shuyo" (Essential Collection of Medical Science) that was translated from Western medical books.

His name appears in "Seiyo Gakka Yakujutsu Mokuroku" (Bibliography of Translations of Western Writings) completed in 1852 and published in 1854, as the author of ten-volume "Iho Shuyo" (Essential Collection of Medical Science) that was translated from Western medical books.

His name appears in "Seiyo Gakka Yakujutsu Mokuroku" (Bibliography of Translations of Western Writings) completed in 1852 and published in 1854, as the author of ten-volume "Iho Shuyo" (Essential Collection of Medical Science) that was translated from Western medical books.

sen.j: 江戸後期の大博物学者で画人である木村蒹葭堂と極めて親密な交流を結んでおり、木村節庵、北村桃庵、藤井鴻平らとならんで、もっとも蒹葭堂と仲が良かった医家の一人であった。
sen.e: He associated himself very closely with Kenkado KIMURA, a great naturalist and painter in the late Edo period, and was one of Kenkado's closest doctors together with Setsuan KIMURA, Toan KITAMURA and Kohei FUJII.

He associated himself very closely with Kenkado KIMURA, a great naturalist and painter in the late Edo period, and was one of Kenkado's closest doctors together with Setsuan KIMURA, Toan KITAMURA and Kohei FUJII.

He associated himself very closely with Kenkado KIMURA, a great naturalist and painter in the late Edo period, and was one of Kenkado's closest doctors together with Setsuan KIMURA, Toan KITAMURA and Kohei FUJII.

sen.j: 『蒹葭堂日記』からは、安永年間から享和年間まで一貫して、月に数度訪れて語らい合わないことがないほど、蒹葭堂の元へと日参していた元恭の姿が窺われる。
sen.e: "Kenkado Nikki" (Diary of Kenkado) indicates that Motoyasu often visited Kenkado, not failing to meet and talk with him several times per month, from Anei to Kyowa era throughout.
"Kenkado Nikki" (Diary of Kenkado) indicates that Motoyasu often visited Kenkado, not failing to meet and talk with him several times per month, from Anei to Kyowa era throughout.
"Kenkado Nikki" (Diary of Kenkado) indicates that Motoyasu often visited Kenkado, not failing to meet and talk with him several times per month, from Anei to Kyowa era throughout.

sen.j: 本草学者としては、蒹葭堂に一番深く関わった人物であった。
sen.e: As a scholar of herbalism, he was the closest person of Kenkado.
As a scholar of herbalism, he was the closest person of Kenkado.
As a scholar of herbalism, he was the closest person of Kenkado.

sen.j: 妹に大高土沙がおり、懐徳堂学主中井履軒の息子で、水哉館館主であった中井柚園に嫁したが（『近世学芸論考-羽倉敬尚論文集-』鈴木淳編、明治書院）、二十五歳の若さで没している。
sen.e: His younger sister Tosa OTAKA married Yuen NAKAI, who was the director of Suisaikan school and whose father was Riken NAKAI, director of Kaitokudo school ("Kinsei Gakugei Ronko - Hagura Keisho Ronbunshu" [Discussion on the Studies in the Early Modern Times - Collected Articles of Keisho HAGURA] edited by Jun SUZUKI and published by Meiji Shoin), but she died at such a young age of 25.

His younger sister Tosa OTAKA married Yuen NAKAI, who was the director of Suisaikan school and whose father was Riken NAKAI, director of Kaitokudo school ("Kinsei Gakugei Ronko - Hagura Keisho Ronbunshu" [Discussion on the Studies in the Early Modern Times - Collected Articles of Keisho HAGURA] edited by Jun SUZUKI and published by Meiji Shoin), but she died at such a young age of 25.

His younger sister Tosa OTAKA married Yuen NAKAI, who was the director of Suisaikan school and whose father was Riken NAKAI, director of Kaitokudo school ("Kinsei Gakugei Ronko - Hagura Keisho Ronbunshu" [Discussion on the Studies in the Early Modern Times - Collected Articles of Keisho HAGURA] edited by Jun SUZUKI and published by Meiji Shoin), but she died at such a young age of 25.

sen.j: 元恭は能登の豪商文人一族岩城氏の、次男善之助を娘婿としており、その子箸尾元市は鴻池家の別家となっている（安岡重明『前期的資本の変質過程：鴻池研究の一節』、宮本又次編『大阪の研究』清文堂. 1970年 第四巻p480）。
sen.e: Motoyasu had a son-in-law called Zennosuke, who was the second son of the Iwaki clan, wealthy family of merchants and literature, and Zennosuke's son Motoichi HASHIO was a member of a branch family of the Konoike family ("Zenkiteki Shihon no Henshitsu Katei: Konoike Kenkyu no Issetsu" [The Process of Changes of Pre-modern Capital - a Study on the Konoike Family] written by Shigeaki YASUOKA, included in page 480, Volume 4 of "Osaka no Kenkyu" [Studies on Osaka] edited by Mataji MIYAMOTO and published by Seibundo in 1970).

Motoyasu had a son-in-law called Zennosuke, who was the second son of the Iwaki clan, wealthy family of merchants and literature, and Zennosuke's son Motoichi HASHIO was a member of a branch family of the Konoike family ("Zenkiteki Shihon no Henshitsu Katei: Konoike Kenkyu no Issetsu" [The Process of Changes of Pre-modern Capital - a Study on the Konoike Family] written by Shigeaki YASUOKA, included in page 480, Volume 4 of "Osaka no Kenkyu" [Studies on Osaka] edited by Mataji MIYAMOTO and published by Seibundo in 1970).

Motoyasu had a son-in-law called Zennosuke, who was the second son of the Iwaki clan, wealthy family of merchants and literature, and Zennosuke's son Motoichi HASHIO was a member of a branch family of the Konoike family ("Zenkiteki Shihon no Henshitsu Katei: Konoike Kenkyu no Issetsu" [The Process of Changes of Pre-modern Capital - a Study on the Konoike Family] written by Shigeaki YASUOKA, included in page 480, Volume 4 of "Osaka no Kenkyu" [Studies on Osaka] edited by Mataji MIYAMOTO and published by Seibundo in 1970).

sen.j: 曾孫に日本人として初の本格的な和英辞典 を作り、清楽研究やピクトリアリスム の研究でも知られ、『冩眞術百科大辞典』を著わした箸尾寅之助 がいる。
sen.e: His great-grandson includes Toranosuke HASHIO, who was the author of the first complete Japanese-English dictionary, and also known for his studies of Qing-era Chinese music and pictorialism and wrote "Shashinjutsu Hyakka Daijiten" (Encyclopedia of Photography).

His great-grandson includes Toranosuke HASHIO, who was the author of the first complete Japanese-English dictionary, and also known for his studies of Qing-era Chinese music and pictorialism and wrote "Shashinjutsu Hyakka Daijiten" (Encyclopedia of Photography).

His great-grandson includes Toranosuke HASHIO, who was the author of the first complete Japanese-English dictionary, and also known for his studies of Qing-era Chinese music and pictorialism and wrote "Shashinjutsu Hyakka Daijiten" (Encyclopedia of Photography).

sen.j: 評価
sen.e: Public Estimation
Public Estimation
Public Estimation

sen.j: 『西洋医事集成宝凾』に校閲者として関わっていることから、蘭学者としての印象が強いが、もともと伝統的な本道医学にも通暁しており、当時毎年発表されていた名医の番付では、橋本宗吉よりもはるかに上位に位置づけられている。
sen.e: Although he is rather imaged as a scholar of Western sciences for his involvement in the revision of "Seiyo Iji Shusei Hokan," he was originally an expert of traditional medicine and ranked far higher than Sokichi HASHIMOTO in the list of good doctors published every year at that time.

Despite his image as a scholar of Western sciences for his involvement in the revision of "Seiyo Iji Shusei Hokan"(Treasure Chest of Collected Western Medical Facts), he was originally an expert of traditional medicine and ranked far higher than Sokichi HASHIMOTO in the list of good doctors published every year at that time.
sen.cmt: ・辞書で調べたところ、be imaged asという表現はあまりしないようなのでDespiteで始まる文に修正しました。・『西洋医事集成宝凾』は（）に英訳を補足しました。
sen.e: Despite his image as a scholar of Western sciences for his involvement in the revision of "Seiyo Iji Shusei Hokan" (Treasure Chest of Collected Western Medical Facts), he was originally an expert of traditional medicine and ranked far higher than Sokichi HASHIMOTO in the list of good doctors published every year at that time.

sen.j: 諸侯から仕官の誘いもしばしばあったが、加賀藩での嘱託医官の仕事をのぞけば、町医としての処世を貫いた。
sen.e: He was often invited to serve various lords, but continued working as a town doctor throughout his life except for performing works commissioned by the Kaga clan.
He was often invited to serve various lords, but continued working as a town doctor throughout his life except for a contract medical officer of the Kaga clan.
sen.cmt: ・「加賀藩での嘱託医官」に関して、用語集の用語検索で「医官」はa medical officer、また英辞郎で「嘱託外科医」はcontract surgeonと出ていたので、それらを参考に修正しました。
sen.e: He was often invited to serve various lords, but continued working as a town doctor throughout his life except for a contract medical officer of the Kaga clan.

sen.j: 本草家として医師の番付に登場することも多かった。
sen.e: He also often appeared as a herbalist in the list of doctors.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: He also often appeared as a herbalist in the list of doctors.
He also often appeared as a herbalist in the list of doctors.

sen.j: 博物学的本草学と蘭学を当時の経済的に豊かな大阪の文化背景のなかで探究したディレッタント(英,伊dilettante、好事家。学者や専門家よりも気楽に素人として興味を持つ者)であった。
sen.e: He was a dilettante (one who studies at ease as a amateur, rather than a scholar or expert) who researched natural historic herbalism and Western sciences in cultural Osaka that was enjoying economic prosperity then.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処「碩学」→修めた学問の広く深いこと（kotobank）
sen.e: He was a dilettante (one who studies at ease as a amateur, rather than a scholar or expert) who researched natural historic herbalism and Western sciences backed by the economically-prosperous culture of Osaka.
sen.cmt: ・「経済的に豊かな大阪の文化背景のなかで」の部分はより簡潔な表現に変えました。
sen.e: He was a dilettante (one who studies at ease as a amateur, rather than a scholar or expert) who researched natural historic herbalism and Western sciences backed by the economically-prosperous culture of Osaka.

sen.j: 一代の碩学である。
sen.e: He was a person of wide and deep knowledge of that time.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: He was a person of wide and deep knowledge of that time.
He was a person of wide and deep knowledge of that time.

sen.j: 著書
sen.e: Work
literary work
sen.cmt: ・文献なのでliteraryを追加しました。
sen.e: literary work

sen.j: 『古今医書目録』四巻、文化元年
sen.e: "Kokin Isho Mokuroku" (Bibliography of Medical Books of Past and Present) - Four volumes, published in 1804
"Kokin Isho Mokuroku" (Bibliography of Medical Books of Past and Present) - Four volumes, published in 1804
"Kokin Isho Mokuroku" (Bibliography of Medical Books of Past and Present) - Four volumes, published in 1804
